description: Premier League clubs rang the changes during the FA Cup third round weekend as top-flight managers up and down the country dealt with the aftermath of another gruelling festive calendar.
title: Bournemouth made 11 changes and won but Newcastle made only one and lost... how Premier League clubs fared with rotation for the FA Cup third round
title_page: Bournemouth made 11 changes and won but Newcastle made only one and lost... how Premier League clubs fared with rotation for the FA Cup third round | Daily Mail Online
text:
Newcastle made only one change for trip to Watford but still lost
Swansea dumped out by Oxford United with only Jack Cork keeping place
Liverpool forced into replay by Exeter after making 10 changes
Premier League clubs rang the changes during the FA Cup third round weekend as top-flight managers up and down the country tried to deal with the aftermath of another gruelling festive calendar.
Bournemouth led the way having made 11 changes from their 0-0 draw at Leicester for the trip to Birmingham City on Saturday.
Eddie Howe's rotation was vindicated as the Cherries emerged 2-1 winners at St Andrew's, while Newcastle made just one change from their defeat by Arsenal on January 2, only to be dumped out of the cup by Watford.
Glenn Murray made the most of a rare opportunity to score Bournemouth's winner against Birmingham
Newcastle named a strong side for their trip to Watford but failed to progress to the fourth round
Liverpool goalscorer Brad Smith was one of 10 changes made by Reds boss Jurgen Klopp against Exeter
Manchester United made three changes for Sheffield United but needed a late Wayne Rooney penalty to win
HOW MANY CHANGES DID EACH PREMIER LEAGUE CLUB MAKE? BOURNEMOUTH 11 LIVERPOOL 10 SWANSEA 10 STOKE 9 EVERTON 8 LEICESTER 8 ASTON VILLA 7 MANCHESTER CITY 7 NORWICH 7 SUNDERLAND 7 TOTTENHAM 7 WEST HAM 7 ARSENAL 5 CHELSEA 4 SOUTHAMPTON 4 WATFORD 4 WEST BROM 4 CRYSTAL PALACE 3 MANCHESTER UNITED 3 NEWCASTLE 1
Injury-ravaged Liverpool were forced into making 10 changes for their trip to Exeter City on Friday night after beating Stoke City in the Capital One Cup on Tuesday only three days following defeat by West Ham in the Premier League.
Left back Brad Smith's late goal kept Jurgen Klopp's side in the hat for the fourth round as the Reds drew 2-2 at St James' Park, with only Christian Benteke keeping his place from the eleven that travelled to Upton Park six days earlier.
Manchester United lumbered past Sheffield United on Saturday thanks to a last minute Wayne Rooney penalty despite Louis van Gaal making only three changes from the starting line-up that beat Swansea a week earlier.
The Swans themselves made 10 changes for the trip to Oxford United on Sunday, only midfielder Jack Cork kept his place, but it was not enough to stop them slipping to a shock 3-2 defeat.
Jonjo Shelvey returned to Swansea's starting line-up against Oxford United but could not avert defeat
Peter Crouch made the most of his inclusion as Stoke beat Doncaster 2-1 after making nine changes
Jonathan Walters and Peter Crouch were the goalscorers as Stoke beat Doncaster Rovers 2-1 to reach the fourth round having made nine changes from the side that lost away at West Brom a week previously.
Leicester were forced into eight changes for their trip to White Hart Lane, but only a late equalising penalty from Harry Kane denied Claudio Ranieri's men straight passage into the fourth round.
Arouna Kone and Kevin Mirallas scored to take Everton through to the fourth round ahead of Dagenham and Redbridge, as Roberto Martinez rotated his squad by making eight changes for the clash at Goodison Park.
Demarai Gray made his Leicester City debut against Tottenham on Sunday as one of eight changes
Arouna Kone scored Everton's first against Dagenham and Redbridge and was one of eight changes
Remi Garde prioritised Aston Villa's Premier League survival scrap by making seven changes for their trip to Wycombe Wanderers on Saturday, but their winless run extended to 16 games as Joe Jacobson's second-half penalty saw the tie finish 1-1.
Ruben Loftus-Cheek was named on the Chelsea bench by Guus Hiddink but earned 45 minuted and a first senior goal as the Blues saw off Scunthorpe United on Sunday, making just four changes from the week before.
Premier League leaders and FA Cup holders Arsenal made five changes for the 3-1 win over Sunderland, but youngster Alex Iwobi was awarded a first start at the Emirates.
Micah Richards scored as Aston Villa drew 1-1 at Wycombe with Remi Garde making seven changes
Ruben Loftus-Cheek scored his first Chelsea goal as Guus Hiddink made four changes for visit of Scunthorpe
Arsenal youngster Alex Iwobi earned his home debut in the 3-1 win over Sunderland on Saturday
